reviewText:
Not a free to play - This is not a free to play game, and it is easy to see that it is not. Most games that are MMO city builders like this rely heavily on users buying boosters. This games does not. First of all, there are only three boosters in the game, and you can not use more than 1 of them per in-game account/city. The boosters that are there give you resources that are helpful to a beginner, but if you build your city up a bit, they can easily be aquired.

PvP - When I first started, I was afraid of going into the PvP part of the game. I was afraid that people who have already made giant cities and huge armies could walk in and take all of my things; this is definitely not the case. They have balanced the game enough so that you can only fight people within 10% of your army strength. 10% is so little, that it makes you rely only on good tactics. It makes EVERY siege/co-op/defence really fun and actually a really good match. Also, most of the online playing is co-op, which is honestly one of the most fun parts of the game. You can raid AI cities or do quests with your friends, and it makes the gameplay really fun, without getting completely screwed over. Also, if you REALLY do not like PvP, you can buy the single player campaign for only $1.99, which is honestly a good deal for how fun this game is.

Building your city - It is hard to build your city at the start, since resources are scarce. This is the point where the co-op takes place and is a big help. You can do quests with your friends and fight armies, and take all of the resources off of their cold dead bodies. This part beats every other city builder into dust. You can actually command your armies, instead of it being auto resolved for you. The game features 3 different races: humans, elves, and orcs. Each race is very balanced, and it would be a very hard decision on if you were to ask which race was the best. This lets you face other online players (or play WITH them) without worrying that their units are SOO much better than yours.

Raiding cities - Later on, once you have a big and tough army, you can start raiding AI cities. There are 30 (from my knowledge) cities that you can siege and either loot or make your vassel. Looting can be helpful, and gives you a lot of resources; while vassels give you resources over time.

Do not be turned away because it is an online city builder. Most of this game is co-op, instead of facing other players. You can join a clan and help each other out by sending each other resources. My in-game name is Enki, for anyone who has any more questions or wants to raid some AI with me! :)

reviewText: I would like to start off by saying that I am a big RTS\RPG fan.  I am also a big fan of ♥♥♥♥♥♥mes.  I have played this game with an open mind, as I suggest anyone else who tries this game, do without having any pre-conceived ideas or expectations.  The game mechanics are very user-friendly and easy to become accostumed to.  I have read many comments regarding the graphics.  Being an older gamer (over 40) I found myself getting a little nostalgic, which I really liked.  The game is excellent.  The concept is great.  The experience is one of the best I have had.  The most appealing aspect of this game, in my opinion, is that it is Free-To-Play.  Keep in mind that it is a RTS game and it will take time to do all the great stuff there is to do in this game.  So without further ado, good luck building your Kingdom and forging your Empire!

reviewText:
This game has been a roller coaster. I first bought it on GameStop because of the promise of a single player mode which did eventually happen. I noticed MAJOR performance hits on Steam and Reverie's developers suggested using their OWN client which users reported provided a MUCH better experience in terms of performance. THEN Reverie discontinued their own client, and even on this I7 rig I have, this game lags and stutters while games like Supreme Commander and Supreme Commander 2 - develpped around the same time and with MUCH larger worlds and literally thousands of units runs beautifully. This game has has a troubled history and a visit to the HeavenGames forum for this game will reveal that history.

The single player risk like portion of the game has been removed. This is strictly a PvP type game. If that's your thing, then you will like this game. I prefer single player and coop PvE.

All of that said, I really hate writing this somewhat negative review as Reverie seem to be a stidio that really wants to make this game something special. The problem however - and you'll note other users have expressed the same concern in the Hub for this game - is that Reverie keeps releasing mega-patches but fails to address core game issues.

When, as a company, ypou get rid of something that improves performance while simiultaneously releasing more and bigger" stuff is really taking one step forward and two steps back. If you'll pardon the trope
date: this COULD have been the RTS fantasy strategy game to rule them all. It isn't unfortunately so it's back to playing Medieval Total War from the physical discs for me. I am sorry Reverie
recommended: you tried but you lack focus."

reviewText:
Welcome to my Review + Game Mechanics Info + Beginners Guide + Tips and Tricks. All the Info I wish I had when i started out.

First I'll do a short review and then get to the rest. I give this game a 7/10. I am loving Kingdom Wars.

There are 2 reasons it does not instantly get a 10/10 from me.

First would be the bugs/glitches which several have been fixed since I started 2 weeks ago.The second reason is lag. The co-op lag can be severe but varies depending on who you are connecting to. Some battles are terrible while others run smooth.

I have been enjoying both PVE and PVP.  The real question is it worth playing? Definately!

Between combat that reminds me of Age of Empires 2 but better and larger. City managment that feels more alive than any pure RTS. A good Economy can speed up your war machine and a bad one can cripple it.

The current 3 races are fairly well balanced with advantages to each.

GAME MECHANICS

-First lets start with Protection". At the start you have 24 real time hours of protection that does not get used when you are offline. This protection prevents any player from attacking you.

Giving new players the time they need to establish themselves. Once disabled protection is gone for good. (So don't disable it!!!)

You can buy more with the uniqe currency "Wealth" AKA "Crowns". You are awarded 1 Hour protection when involved in pvp battles win or lose. When Co-Oping a quest or siege the person  INVITING can have protection. The person being INVITED cannot have protection.

-Buildings can level up. Up to level 5. Each level reduces cost of units
recommended: costs of repairs by 4% of price. It also creates units equal to the buildings current level.\n\n-Each unit can go to level 20. Each level you get 3 skill points to place in different stats such as Damage
hoursPlayed: Hit points
voteText: Health Regen
helpfulPercent:
Movement speed or Resists to slashing/piercing ect. Allowing you to make extremely hard to kill Archers or a savage blitzkrieg of Melee. The choice is yours.

-Heros. This special character you start with and the others you can recruit. A Dwarven Champion or a Orc Shaman to the dreaded Hydra or DRAGON!

Anyone who builds/researches the right stuff can recruit these units. Each hero is immortal so they cannot die. They can be defeated or knocked out. Most Heros can reach up to level 60. Your main Hero and Wizards can go to lvl 100. A fully leveled hero is a force to be reckoned with. Each one with it's own special abilities.

-The online matchmaking system requires armies be equal strength to Co-op anthing or to PVP a player. A difference of up to 10% in army strength is allowed. Meaning no new player will be met by a army of dragons and knights.

Army strength is determined by the number of units in the army
votesHelpful:
what type of unit it is and what levels they are.

-After protection is off and you are attacked by a player you can pay them off instead of battling. Price varies depending on strengths and units involved.

-You can make up to 5 armies at the start. Upgrading to 10 once you have joined a alliance
votesTotal:
built a Guild Hall and researched additional armies.

-Population and Caps. At first your population cap in the home city is 50 but you can research Land Plots at the town center to increase this to 90. Unforuntaly that is the cap for home.

However armies have thier own cap which is at 60. You can have 5 armies with 300 units total cap at start and a total of 10 for 600 units in armies in late game.

You can also siege NPC cities and take them as vassals allowing you to store troops
votesFunny: resources or villagers in them. Greatly increasing economy
commentsCount:
army size and storage overall.

*Your gold cap is equal to the resource cap. Building houses beyond POP limit increases storage. Building additional barns increases storage cap by 1000 each.

-Wealth AKA "Crowns" are the special currency of this game. You need these to build the best buildings
column16:
units & researching tech AKA The Good Stuff.

You get crowns for winning or losing in pvp the amount is significant but varies depending on the size of armies involved. Sieges of cities in the open world (NPC cities) can reward significant amounts of crowns and resources.

Each quest awards 4 crowns and clearing a area of enemys completely rewards 1 crown. There is also a daily reward for logging in which varies but you can get 1 crown instead.

All of which is doubled if you upgrade to a premium account. Crowns flow once you get established.

GUIDE FOR NEW PLAYERS

I am a Human so some things may be human specific but I will try to keep it as general as I can.

-With 24 hours of protection. No player can attack you. Focus on your economy. With the newest patch your gatherers gain resources 10x faster than usual at the start and that slows to normal the further you get. So you can do less then what I suggest (or do it for a awesome economy).

-Create 3 villagers at your town hall (you start with it) and create a barn at the same time.

-Once the barn is built. Begin by making 5 pigs and then a total of 7 groups of villagers. Assign each villager to livestock.

When you click on a unit thier picture shows in bottom left around the picture are symbols for actions or if the unit has formations
column17:
special abilites ect. In villagers case you can assign it to take care of livestock.

This is the fastest way to create food at your home city. Cows and Fields are slower overall. Fields and Bushes are not available in winter. Cows are slow to develop and produce less than pigs.

When you have a steady food supply keep making more villagers. To have a great economy you will need 30-35 villagers to cover all tasks.

-Assign 10 villagers to cutting wood. If you prefer archers over melee you may want to go after more wood but with economic boost (which I never experianced) I don't think more will be needed. Even my current numbers may be overkill. Lucky new people XD

-When it comes to mining I prefer Gold. I have met some who have focused on stone and then sold stone for gold. I suggest assigning 10 villagers to Gold mining and another 5 villagers to Stone mining. Each lump of stone or gold on the map in your city can support 2 villagers mining it.

Remember to make a horse cart from your barn and place it nearby any mining operations. The horse cart acts as a supply drop point. Keeping one near any group of gatherers prevents them from walking all the way back to the town hall to drop what they gather. You do not need one for livestock as long as you keep them near the town center.

Now you should have a Excellent Economy and ready to build your barracks
column18:
archery and stable. I recommend starting with the barracks. I prefer swordsmen over maces they are more expensive but easier to keep alive. Also a all around better unit.

I suggest 4 units to do quests in home area. 12 units total to do quests safely outside home area. Players new to RTS games should x2 those amounts and veterans won't need this XD.

TIPS & TRICKS

You don't need walls or soldiers in the home city. Have no walls and only villagers. Keep soldiers outside of town in armies. Most people don't use armies with 75 Strength (75villagers would be 75 str keep 15 empty to build soldiers and heal damaged units) and it is cheap to pay off enemies when they attack. Best economy in the game but no defensive siege battles until you have vassals.

Armies don't have to be just a army. Create a army of villagers
column19:
make a camp and assign them to chopping wood or mining gold. A group of horse carts to haul the loot you get after sieging a enemy or clearing a area. The cart army returns to base doing a supply run as you siege another location.

Make a camp in enemy land. You can hire enemy racial units as mercenaries.

2 weeks of knowledge crammed into a TL;DR review... If you feel pity for this nerd please use my reference code once in this great game.  REF1100001044EAE12"

reviewText:
I have played this game for a few hours now.  It does need some work, its sluggish in areas, and it can be unforgiving.  The game has tons of potential!  I have enjoyed the time I have played.  If I knew that the game plays the way it does then I would have got it when it was Dawn of Fantasy and you had to pay for it.  Thats how much I like it right now.  If this opinion changes I will update.

Ok.  I still really like this game.  I am noticing some bugs.  I have an issue when I try to start a quest on the world map it will not load correctly and I have to restart the game.  Also there seems to be some sorta disconnect between what happens on the quests and what my army is like when I get back to the world map.

This game has awesome potential.  The devs. are working to make it more polished.  After a few fixes and maybe a graphical overhaul (not horrible but could really be better) this could be one of the best fantasy empire building games I have played.

reviewText:
Feels a lil glued up in the unit tasking, but other than that looks good in my mind and instantly had a lil bit of a Black and White feel to it. I like that units are in platoons, but a more Total war approach with unit orders in battle would be nice. I give it a personal 8/10

Edit 1:

So now that Ive gotten some more time in the game, I must say Ive been gladly surprised with Kingdom Wars. However, as with any game, there are problems, and Ill try my best to be the most helpful I can to new players and to the devs in ideas I have.

1. units orders: The manner in which units are ordered around the battlefield is good to a point, but seriously sucks in combat. Basically, if you arn't used to normal RTS games and using those command groups, then be prepared to be annoyed. The forming of solid lines of defense/attack are simple to the point of insanity. You either just run everything up at once, save for cavalry and archers, and hope you win or you take too long to form proper lines and risk taking huge damaged from enemy archer or crossbowmen in the process. The way to fix this in my mind would be to rip the current system and add in a more Total war type of battle system, making for a more fluid experience (Or just add in the ability to lock different formations to a hotkey, Idk)

2. The economy: This games economy surprised me for the better in some areas, but I found lack luster in others. The dominate reliance on wood is good, but the ability to build houses out of stone instead of wood would make for the bigger projects and upgrades coming faster, and make the city look better if they had the textures to match. The crown system is amazing, being a resource that you gain from gold instead of a bought currency for real money, and making it essential to manage your crown total very carefully so not to leave you without that one vital upgrade. The food resource in this game also makes for fun play in that there are not just farms but also animals to use to produce and it just adds a much greater sense of life to your city.

3. The combat: The full on combat of this game is the biggest complaint I have. It seems that the battles try to simulate tactics, but in the end it seems all that is needed is to have a direct line to enemy units and just be a Russian as possible (Quantity wins) I would recommend changing it up to make it so certain units like the crossbowmen would do so much damage that it basicallly one hits units. Another this is the special units. Through the quests I recieved a Dragonslayer, which in my mind, would be fairly good agaisnt Dragons. But when I sent him agianst the Dragon that spawned as part of the quest, well, lets just say the rest of my army was quickly heading that way. I believe that some of the special units should be very, very good against what they are meant to go against.

This is my current review, as I discover more of the game and figure it out for myself, Ill let every one know what I think, still a 8/10.

A video review will be uploaded within the next day or two, will post link with this written one.

reviewText:
Don't be turned down by the fact that it's a town and resource management game, as there are no pay-to-win elements anywhere. In fact, people complain on a daily basis that real money isn't worth anything.

This game has many realistic elements but it is not a low-fantasy. There are three playable races: Humans, Elves, and Orcs. Later on, dwarves will become available for hire and dragons will be tamable.

At the start of the game, you are a minor nobleman granted an estate by your liege. You will then work your way up to true knighthood, and eventually have vassals of your own. Your town will grow larger and larger, eventually with hundreds of peasants at your command (not hundreds of peasant units, simply that there are 10 in each unit, to prevent confusion). They will till and work the land for you. Eventually, you will go beyond your estate and vassalize your neighbors through complicated and realistic siege warfare.

Now to the gameplay: The game functions like a town/resource management thrown in with some Warcraft III elements. You order workers to cut wood, mine, and then use the resources to build walls and buildings, and eventually muster an army to attack your neighbors.

There are still several bugs, but all of them minor and they benefit the player more than they do any harm. The developers are also always online and very active so there aren't any things that go unnoticed.


Overall: 8/10. The best town/resource management game I have played thus far, despite not really liking the genre previously. I recommend this game to anyone looking for a casual game.

reviewText:
Been playing the past few days and I feel like I can finally make a decent review. Does not seem to have many pay to win aspects to it which is very good for a free to play game. Can get a $10 and $20 pack which will put you ahead but does not seem to give you anything you cant get already, devs need to eat too. Has a sort of Age of Empires feel to it which i like.

Unit pathing currently seems to be a bit derpy but definitely not a game killer as im sure it will be fixed. Some other bigs here and there but no game breakers and im sure theyll be hammered out soon so that wont rly affect my judgement much.

Be warned if youre at 90 pop cap in your city do not try to keep buying houses to increase your population, price will increase and youll keep paying wood but no new houses, they should definitely disable the button once you hit the cap, again nothing really major just something that made me a bit sad when i realized what happened.

Game has a bit of a learning curve (like any mmo / rts). Could likely use some pop up hints perhaps to help new players along. Few of my friends i brought along to play were getting frustrated and i had to help em along, Which isnt a big deal i could just see players not having someone to help them simply giving up out of frustration. Yes i know there are tutorials in the game but lets be honest. Aint nobody got time for dat.

Other than those few things which werent really al lthat bad i cant really think of anything negative so now ill start on the positive!

Siege warfare seems so far to be implemented pretty well, I like the different world view and city views. You definitely have an mmo feel to it with the quests and your hero but also functions as a very good RTS, They have balanced it pretty well which makes this game pretty unique.

I like the trading you can do in the game as well, different cities seem to have different prices for goods which also seems to fluctuate. Gives you something else to do other than the regular quest / kill grind.

Early game they have you start off pretty well. You have an income boost which helps a whole lot and really gives you a good nudge to get growing quick, I like the fact that they did this as it makes it so there is little down time / sitting around waiting for resources to accumilate.

Different races seem to have different ways of collecting resources, for example orcs dont have farms like humans and they must hunt. Not too sure on elves as i have not played them but differences like this really make each race feel different and adds new things for you to do and new ways for you to play which can keep this game feeling fresh and new for a long time.

Normally when i see a currency in a free to play game (crown in this game) I immediately have a bad feeling about the pay to win aspects. They seem to have made it so that after every battle or quest you get crowns, and you dont really need too many to progress. and the packs you are able to buy are limited to one per city slotso someone cant spend all this money and get 10 million crowns. Kudos to the devs on that one.

Well thats pretty much all i could think of off the top of my head. Overall i would rate this game at a 7-9/10 (7-9 only because i feel like i would need to play to the end game in order to really be sure)

reviewText:
Kingdom Wars is an RPG Indie-Strategy game. It takes place long ago. You can choose from being Elves, Men, or Orcs. You are also able to choose from three different starting locations. As you progress through the game, you learn more and more about the lore. I, truly, very much like this game. It has all the things I like. If you have ever played Sid Meier's Civilization IV, Beyond the Sword/Warlords, or Civilization V, you will notice a lot of similarities. This game will keep you occupied for hours, and I, personally, reccomend this game to people like me who LOVE old fighting styles, and LOVE a good RPG/Strategy game.

9.5/10

I'm sure there are many great things to come with this game.

reviewText: I've played alot of stratigy games over the years and the one thing alot of them seem to lack is story. Kingdom Wars actually gives you a bit of background on what's going on in the world. A reason to go out and conquer.  Being the huge nerd that I am, I am part of a renaissance group who studies and reenacts historical battles in real life. I like the diversity of figthers and fighting styles. Halbreders are good against horses, sword men with shields are good against defending arrows and so on. This gives battle a bit more realism for me.  On top of that there is customization to your heros and armies and it's not rediculously expensive to do so. This is one of the few free to play games I acutally put money into customization because I know I will play it for awhile. There is a slight lack of options in the customization department but it is a young game still and I am sure that will grow. All in all I think the game is pretty great so far.

reviewText:
I rarely write reviews but as a game tester for alpha, beta, and online mmos, i do gotta say this has been a very pleasent supprise. This is one of the few games that don't build hype to let players down. Theres not much pay to win, theres a great ballance with the units of the game, and all in all its a strong well crafted idea which I can very much put in 50 - 80 hours into this game.

I do gotta say alot of the times rts are more like a gamble then strategy and this game is more of a gamble situation. Basically during battle the enemies have a range of aggro and thats really about it. I don't mind that as any war is a gamble of strength, luck, and some strategy and manuvering involved and this does put this very well.

There is one otherthing that might be a bug is that the selection rectangle stays on the screen sometimes when you select a unit. Not a game breaker but it is a glitch they should look into.

So far they have troop training as you enter cities, looting corpses with civs, and buying mercs and selling loot you get from enemies.

The map is quite big and you can coop or even vs enemy players in segies and other pvp battles. I haven't got to test that part out yet, but you basically get your own map to your self to train your army anyway. Mount and blade strategy meet rts for the first time! It is defeently one of the more interesting games that i've seen and as a avid gamer, I am quite picky about what I play.

I hope this helps!

reviewText:
This is a great game, it has many casual gameplay elements taken from Rome total war, and some building elements from The Settlers (7?). Controlling your army, and leveling them up on the over world is great fun, building your city and aquiring upgrades also plays out well. The timers on building buildings don't hit as hard as I initially thought they would, with twenty minute build timers on some of the larger buildings passing by quickly as I focus on other portions of the game

I have to say, that by far, BY FAR, i enjoyed the first part of the game the most, the psuedo tutorial. Running around with my hero and a few units, clearing my lands from bandits, coming back to find a messenger had arrived, or a lord wanted me to do something was thrilling and immersive.

The game looks fantastic for how many units are on the screen at once, and every battle I find myself Roleplaying as my hero, and ordering my units to take the field and feeling the loss of every man in all of my squads.

The only thing I really dislike are the crown earning systems, I find the process too slow, where PvP may net you the most crowns the fastest, that can come at the total loss of your army (save for maybe one or two units if you are lucky), which means it's back to the drawing board to re level up your units. (You can also buy your units levels at nearby towns with in game gold)

You could also take your leveled army, and farm the overworld maps for crowns, but after the third run through of a map, I find myself getting tired of the same placement of units, the same patrol paths, the same spawn point. Vary up the maps a bit more, is all I ask, make the single player overworld a bit more varied for map selection, instead of relying on the same one or two exactly the same maps per section.

It's a great free to play game if you are into city builders with PvP elements. Enjoy it while it lasts.

reviewText: I've played alot of stratigy games over the years and the one thing alot of them seem to lack is story. Kingdom Wars actually gives you a bit of background on what's going on in the world. A reason to go out and conquer.  Being the huge nerd that I am, I am part of a renaissance group who studies and reenacts historical battles in real life. I like the diversity of figthers and fighting styles. Halbreders are good against horses, sword men with shields are good against defending arrows and so on. This gives battle a bit more realism for me.  On top of that there is customization to your heros and armies and it's not rediculously expensive to do so. This is one of the few free to play games I acutally put money into customization because I know I will play it for awhile. There is a slight lack of options in the customization department but it is a young game still and I am sure that will grow. All in all I think the game is pretty great so far.

reviewText: I started playing this game last night and though I have only just begun it seems like I will enjoy it quite a bit. I like the strategic aspects of the game as well as the ease at which it can be picked up. There does not seem to be a pay wall as much of the items listed in the shop are things that do not seem overly difficult to attain in the game itself. The trade system could maybe use some work. I have tried doing the quest to trade cows and I cannot seem to get it to finish. Maybe i am doing something wrong but I feel it could be something to work on either way. That however would really be my only complaint so far. The game is fun and I love that I can build a castle for myself. I have not tried playing with a friend yet but I will have to do that very soon. I plan on telling some of my friends to join because it seems like it will be really fun to play this with them. Overall I rate this game as an 8/10 so far. A good fun strategy game that is not overly difficult to get a grasp on the concepts. Definitely a solid game.

reviewText: Somehow the Game Stronghold Online could have been. The troops are well balanced, allthough you need to get to know them to use them right. The three races are all provided with weakness and strength so the choice of race is rather a choice of taste. reviewText:
I rarely write reviews but as a game tester for alpha, beta, and online mmos, i do gotta say this has been a very pleasent supprise. This is one of the few games that don't build hype to let players down. Theres not much pay to win, theres a great ballance with the units of the game, and all in all its a strong well crafted idea which I can very much put in 50 - 80 hours into this game.

I do gotta say alot of the times rts are more like a gamble then strategy and this game is more of a gamble situation. Basically during battle the enemies have a range of aggro and thats really about it. I don't mind that as any war is a gamble of strength, luck, and some strategy and manuvering involved and this does put this very well.

There is one otherthing that might be a bug is that the selection rectangle stays on the screen sometimes when you select a unit. Not a game breaker but it is a glitch they should look into.

So far they have troop training as you enter cities, looting corpses with civs, and buying mercs and selling loot you get from enemies.

The map is quite big and you can coop or even vs enemy players in segies and other pvp battles. I haven't got to test that part out yet, but you basically get your own map to your self to train your army anyway. Mount and blade strategy meet rts for the first time! It is defeently one of the more interesting games that i've seen and as a avid gamer, I am quite picky about what I play.

I hope this helps!
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is a great game, it has many casual gameplay elements taken from Rome total war, and some building elements from The Settlers (7?). Controlling your army, and leveling them up on the over world is great fun, building your city and aquiring upgrades also plays out well. The timers on building buildings don't hit as hard as I initially thought they would, with twenty minute build timers on some of the larger buildings passing by quickly as I focus on other portions of the game

I have to say, that by far, BY FAR, i enjoyed the first part of the game the most, the psuedo tutorial. Running around with my hero and a few units, clearing my lands from bandits, coming back to find a messenger had arrived, or a lord wanted me to do something was thrilling and immersive.

The game looks fantastic for how many units are on the screen at once, and every battle I find myself Roleplaying as my hero, and ordering my units to take the field and feeling the loss of every man in all of my squads.

The only thing I really dislike are the crown earning systems, I find the process too slow, where PvP may net you the most crowns the fastest, that can come at the total loss of your army (save for maybe one or two units if you are lucky), which means it's back to the drawing board to re level up your units. (You can also buy your units levels at nearby towns with in game gold)

You could also take your leveled army, and farm the overworld maps for crowns, but after the third run through of a map, I find myself getting tired of the same placement of units, the same patrol paths, the same spawn point. Vary up the maps a bit more, is all I ask, make the single player overworld a bit more varied for map selection, instead of relying on the same one or two exactly the same maps per section.

It's a great free to play game if you are into city builders with PvP elements. Enjoy it while it lasts.

reviewText: Hi.   Ok, I'm a newb, just a few hours played.   Look at it this way, I have over 50 games in steam, haven't played more than a day in most of them, this one, I'm on my 3rd day.  I like the art.  I like having quests mainly because I'm retired and old and don't want to think too much.  I seem to have a little trouble with losing workers somewhere and haven't figured how to find them yet.  I'd like more tooltips with more info, I'd like to pause without logging out if no one's attacking me.... just because going pee (I'm old, it takes a while and often) and you come back and whatever you killed quest-wise has resurrected (it took me a while to figure out you gotta finish any quests you start before logging out, I was thinking I was having a senior moment and never really did what I thought I did -- which is scary)  I do feel like I need LOTS more direction and explaination.  Any way to move that chat box?  I like to listen in but it's in the way.The music is nice but I find myself nodding off.  This little box is filling up.  Oh, soon I'll be vulnerable... does a guy joining this late have a chance of survival if attacked?  lbattros@hotmail.com.

reviewText: Kingdom Wars is a very unique and addictive MMORTS. You attack, defend, and manage a kindom with the option of three playable races each differning in their own unique ways. You start off with a simple kingdom, but in time it can easily grow and prosper into a epic empire. It is not a pay to win type of game either. With both time and skill you can easily succed in this game. I definatly recommend to strategic players.

reviewText: The game is great. I love basically every single aspect of it so far. The races are well different to make them unique (unlike just changing the units a little bit, each race has different mechanics, which is a must for any great RTS). The Microtransaction shop seems to sell some pretty nice customization for your town, + I love the way the whole game works by having a main town to work around, instead of building a settlement in one match than a new one in a later match. The map seems to be well done and different from area to area (seems like there are some unpopulated areas that may be used for future races, but I can't tell). The graphcis are nice. Many people complain about them, but I absolutely love em'. They look like what a nice RTS should look like. This is a game I surely look forward to playing further and maybe even spending some money on microtransactions. Keep up the good work!

reviewText:
I played Dawn of Fantasy back in its early closed beta. It was...horrible. So many game breaking glitches, errors, units disappearing, the hero disappearing...just so many things. Luckily, the developpers are always on the prowl so they listened to everything we had to say...and they still do today. I've rarely seen developpers being so active, especially for such a lengthy amount of time.

Now...I have yet to find a single bug. It took some time, but the game is in a great functioning state. There are a little jitters here and there, but they don't cause any real problems.

This game has three races: Orks, Elves, and Humans. There is also the rumor of the possible coming undead race, but let's not get ahead of ourselves. (See...See what I did there? Ahead? You know...un...undea-Headless Horseman...)

Unlike many other RTS games where the differences are just aesthetical or very minor, all three races are heavily different from eachother. Where humans use peasants to mine, chop wood, and kill livestock, elves need wood spirits to gather wood. And the other races do not have the same form of livestock as the humans. Elves have unicorns and Orks have a type of 'boar'. Both can be used in combat and, while the boar can be killed and have its meat taken, the unicorns give a steady trickle of gold (and can be used to protect your gatherers from wolves).

When you create a new race, you have the option to choose from three different regions of that race's territories. The only thing that changes, I've noticed, is the landscape. This affects the placement of your soon-to-be walls and will create different kinds of tactics when attacking and defending players/npc towns. Afterwards, you have the option of choosing between different traits that will become permanent for that city, although the region you choose already possesses a few natural traits that will be added to your two choices. This makes some strategic decisions on developping your region change, as the traits affect ressource income, training, building, and stats of units.

Units are also varied. Where humans have a good balance between unit types (melee, range, siege, cavalry), orks are more centered around melee, health, and anger issues, while elves are more centered around range and speed. I might be mistaking, but this is how I've percieved all three.

Some units have abilities specific to them, such as human knights being able to heal nearby units or the elves ranged cavalry being able to use an arrow volley (accelerates their firing rates).

For you, the player, you are represented by a 'hero' (that you can rename with crowns. More on those later). This hero allows you to interact with NPCs on the maps, allowing you to buy and sell ressources, buy mercenaries (this is the only way to get units from the other factions), or train your troops (including your hero). To travel on the world map, you need your hero to lead the army that you create. Depending on what units you bring with you, the amount of ressources you can carry with you increases. You can only carry a certain amount of wood, meat, and stone, so be cautious. As for your gold, you can carry however much you want! Except 'thieves' will start stealing the amount that exceeds your ressource cap. This also happens in your town.

You have several options when travelling on the world map. You can set up a camp (with three defensive levels depending on the ressources that army possesses) which allows you to attack player cities. These camps can let you mine for ressources (if you have gatherers) and recruit units from your race to bolster your sieging force. You can also fight on the map, allowing you to see what is in the region. If you do it from a camp, you'll have a place to retreat to if you're overwhelmed. If you have no defences, well...
This is a great way to see the regions without towns or cities. Sssilistra, for example...Nah. Why would I spoil that for you?

You can also siege the npc towns on the map and conquer them, they become 'allied' with you. Plus, you get to loot the corpses on that map if you have gatherers and won. Hooray for corpse desecration! Otherwise, there's not much use with allying with npc towns apart from trading, but that only gives you a fickle amount of ressource income.

Sieging can be slow, especially with the accuracy provided by your trebuchets/siege catapults/ bolt throwers, and with the many defenses that can be placed in a city or town, you best be wise on where you go to fight as you can be annihilated in just a few seconds. The fun part is when you enter the city after tearing down the walls and the defenses.

Now, there's the matter of crowns and special units. Before you ask; No. The special units do not cause a pay-to-win situation. They can killed just as easily as any other unit...sometimes. It depends on the unit. First, let's talk about crowns. Crowns are the special currency bought with in-game money, but they can also be obtained in-game via combat and completing quests. These are used for research and constructing certain buildings. The demands for the buildings are minor and will certainly just take you a single trip on the world map and 'entering the region' to get the crowns needed. A few bandits and there you go. You got your building plus some extra. You might've gotten enough for the beginner's research too!

Now, for the special units. Before the game became free to play, you just needed enough crowns to buy a dwarf unit or a dragon from the market. Now, you need not only the crowns, but the building as well, and these take a CRAZY amount of ressources to build! Not only that, but you have the crowns that are eaten up by the buildings. This prevents everyone from having too many of these units seeing how powerful they are. I find it both logical and crippling when thinking about the research needed to unlock the spells for the three mage types (provided you even manage to recruit one). You can no longer get tons of dragons or hydras as, to do so, you need to build several of the buildings dedicated to recruiting them seeing as only one beast cage can sustain one dragon or hydra. This is a good thing as, before the regulation of its power, a dragon could annihilate entire groups of units with a single fireball, not to mention the fire spreading in the town and destroying everything but the walls.

Now, it's reasonably powerful, but cannot do anything on its own. It can't. Don't even try. I'm serious. Don't make it walk over there on its own. Because of these extreme limitations on the special units, you're still depending heavily on your regular units. Not only that, but player towns might harbor a dragon, so I would advise you to carry a dragon slayer, if you can get him out of the tavern.

Another feature related to PVP is the protection time. You can buy this from the barracks for crowns. There's a large amount of different times, so don't worry. The timer does not keep going when you've logged out. It resumes when you continue playing in that town, however. Building and ressource gathering continues.

As for the simpler things, I cannot percieve graphics the same as other people, so, for me, these are still pretty good. The music fits the time period this is set in and doesn't disappoint, although more variety would be needed.

The game isn't perfect, but perfection leads to stagnation.

reviewText:
Graphics:
+ Good effects
+ Great animated units
+ Huge and great map

Sound:
+ Good music
+ Good weapons sounds
+ Moderate sounds for effects

Balance:
+ Good balance between Races, and also they work on it with the patches

Atmosphere:
+ Amazing escenario
+ A realistic atmosphere make you feel to be inside of the siege!
+ Moderate Storyline

Control:
+ Easy to control the Units
+ Good tutorial

Game Size:
+ Lots of citys to conquer and have fun
+ Great customization
+ Different missions
+ Pvp mode
+ Takes sometime to farm to get stuff, thing that make the game much better (No matter what those players that wants everything easy says)
- Just a few factions and a limited ammount of units to recruit (Could be much more! )

Level Design:
+ Big maps
- Can be repetitive


This MMORTS is one of those games you MUST play and keep on your playlist, it will provide you a lot of hours of fun and entretainment. The dificulty of the game may vary so you can have easy or hard fun!

reviewText: So I bought this game in 2012 after it was fairly new. Keep in mind, this game was new at the time and was still getting sorted out. I played for 100+ hours in the first week, It brought me in and it kept me wanting to come back and play more. I had to get the walls built, I needed to build that army, I needed to siege  that city. This game has improved more than I could have imagined since then. I literally bought it a second time because I couldnt resist, Now after a year and a half break I am back. I was able to import all of my old cities and pick up right where I left off. This game is great in the RTS aspect. Lots of units, versatile factions, even the ability to conquer other cities. It also has great strategy becaus every unit has a weakness, but it also a strong point which could help to change the tide of a battle. I recommend this game to anyone who is looking for an enjoyable, laid back, RTS. The mods are great and the community is a lot of fun. This is a game thatcould get you hooked.

reviewText:
I love this game cant stop playing it,I havent got to do any pvp yet as my army aint strong enought but looking foward to it also you dont have to spend a penny of your money to win its all completely free.
I would recommend doing the tutorial first it dose'nt take long and shows you enough to get started.

Pros..
as always everything uses resources but they are easy to come by you either farm for them using your peasants, trade goods and livestock for gold to buy them or just buy them with what gold you have instock by going to other towns you can also gather resources by taking peasants out with you to combat to loot the bodys.
The building side of the game is easy just click on the building you want to construck and it starts building, it takes time and patients but feels great when you finish, I cant wait till i have a full sized kingdom.
When it come to the army its so much fun watching the battles im impressed with the way you can control your individual units unlike some mmo's where its hard to control and keep track of your men this game tops it, the controls are easy just assinge a group to a hotkey and access them at a touch of a button, also the different formations prove very useful when in combat.
If your not ready to go out and attack a fort then just go out and you can fight againt pvp who have the same sized army as you,combat is great fun i love watching a hundred men battle it out but its not just a case of run in and chop away you have to be very strategic plan your moves and organise you army accordingly.

Cons..
I have only one problem.
It can get rather expensive on resouces as you kingdom grows so it take a long time to progress.

Overall this game is great so get it a.s.a.p

reviewText:
The best way to describe this game is by this short sentence: Real time strategy meets MMO".
We all know that will be your response.
Well yeah .... the question is ... is it good?
Short answer: Yes.
Long answer: It's complicated.
The good:
- it's free
- the tech tree is quite well defined and the progession is not to difficult
- the units have nice upgrades at level up (and yes the units level up)
date:
and it makes sense to have a main army that you carefully level up to a good level and have that as the main force in PVP later on

The bonus ( :D ):

reviewText:
I want to first start out by saying, I have owned this game since beta, So I have been through all the Bugs and junk like most games when they first come out.....

Game Review goes down like this

You can Custom each unit as well as your Castle, different textures armours and how they fight for example you want Knights with tons of Arrow defense and huge hitting power or low hitting power but can heal up super fast. I guess once you lvl up your units it will somewhat blend in as there are caps...

Main types of people you can play ORCS, Elfs and Human. I play Human as my main and Orcs... I hate elves!!!

It is not a Pay to win game as it has a system to match people up to somewhat equal balance. The graphics are great, now I have a power house machines so I can't really speak if there is lag or Frame rate issues as I get max all the time. The map and fights are pretty dynamic and if you are a Total War fan this might be your game!! It is also a full RTS game no turn base crap which is nice. I have a O.K army with 1 Red Dragon and a few Minotaurs LOVE Minotaurs. Most people have a lot of playing methods. lots of people like Archers and some like things that can run fast and destroy Archers like Minotaurs hehe. Your Kingdom is setup in such a way that if you get a attacked you have a chance to win if you play smart. You will always retain your Castle if you lose and it is pretty easy to fix it back up.  I would suggest playing solo a few matches to see what your base can do and find the weaknesses.

There are plenty of people so lvling up makes it easy. You can lvl up really fast so don't think you will be left behind, this games some what take care of that weakness really good. They have units that you can buy with crowns find out what type of fighter you want to be then unless your power...


Crowns that word can be scary but like I said this is not a Pay to win game.... So you can earn crowns pretty easy by fighting and doing all the quest... Now I hope the devs still do this, but they are know to give out 100 crowns for just being nice in chat.... or helping others, I have received close to 300 crowns in total over the years.

Devs,, they listen for the most part and seem to have a great connection to the chat channels, patches come out pretty quick and all the extra content is free.

PS there is a way to have to have a full Dwarf Army very bad ♥♥♥. I have 50% full army now that I am lvling up.

Thank for reading my wall of text..... See you out there

reviewText:
Kingdom Wars is not for everyone. It is a slow, complex game, though that's not to say it's any more complex than your average RTS. Starting the game the first time has a steep learning curve of about 7 hours. You have to learn all your normal RTS things like what buildings can go where to make what, what upgrades are available to each unit, basic economy & tactics, etc. But then there is an overworld map, quests, army management, sieges, and a tight constraint on crowns/influence, which is the reward for beating quests and winning combat and absolutely necessary not only for research but for special units, too. And consider this: there is a PvP element, which you either can bypass by paying off the attacker or engage and risk your units, and either way you can only rest safe for one hour of in-game time before you can attack/be attacked again. So you start off with 24 hours of in-game PvP protection. Just 24 game hours to prepare for PvP.

PvE is all about quests and getting crowns/influence through quests and battling on the overworld (think random battles from older Final Fantasy games but you choose when & where.) One big flaw is the cumbersome quest system which makes you inch your way over the worldmap to the quest giver's city and then load the city map and then wait while your hero runs across the city to the quest giver. And turning in a quest often results in another one being available, but you have to exit the city and enter it again, walk your hero back to the quest giver and get the next quest in the chain. Most quests are repetitive, and don't directly scale in difficulty. You will often have to fight two armies, seige two cities, etc. and both often occur on the same map, but you have to, again, inch your way over the overworld map to get from point to point. Now the idea behind this is while one army is moving up to four additional armies can be deployed as well. This makes it possible to split your forces and multi-task on the world map, building an ever bigger collective army.

Battles can be quick, though. I got to a point in the quests where I decided I would have my hero kill eveything solo, and that takes forever. But if you don't go Hero vs. World, seiging a castle can be quick, routing an army can be quick, it all depends on your playstyle and how much you risk your units, if you worry about looting every penny, spending every skill point asap, etc.

This is the kind of game like OgreBattle where you can easily drop 80 hours and not even see a fraction of what there is to achieve in the game. This game is a place to escape reality and become absorbed in the fantasy RTS game, with the added pluses and minuses of PvP. There are so many details, potential strategies, and an ever unlocking complexity that keeps you learning well past the 30 hours I've put into this game so far. Despite the flaws, it is easy to get absorbed. Come and stay. We don't bite - much. :)

reviewText:
The game starts off with you and your hero in a humble little town that you have just aquired. You are given quests that you can follow for rewards, and get you familiarized with the game. In the beginning you are placed in a status with a timer that counts down, and after the amount of ingame hours expire you can now be attacked by armies of relatively the same strength as your own

Or

You can avoid the quests, try and build your army and city your own way, go on the march, start pvp by turning off the protective status mode, going on a coop raid of a city. Whatever you decide to do, the beginning may feel a little harsh because the gathering process feels really slow until you get everything rolling. Your units keep gathering resources while you are offline and there are daily rewards mailed to your in-game bank.

The game has a sort of Knights of Honor" and "Warcraft 3" feel to it.

KOH because: There are some diplomacy aspects that can be done with the NPC cities like giving gifts and trading with them to improve relations. NPC cities that you defeat can either be looted for additional resources or placed into vassalage under your command and there are alliances that can be made with other players. reviewText: This is by far one of the games that you're looking for, if you're on real time strategy games, immersive gameplay also really fun to play, the first hours might be rough for some people, but you can enjoy everything about it, there are 3 races with plenty of strength and weakness (humans, elves and orcs, pretty nice people that always help you and they are fun to chat with, it's an awesome community, it's not a pay to win game... it's more like a learn to play and win game, you can't be bullied by people more powerful than you, they have a pretty balance pvp system, there's something here that you can't find in any other game and makes it great and kinda addictive, also pretty good moderators, i recommend this game, for new players and for veterans, because of the always challenging gameplay, build your village, establish an economy, build your army, rise an stronghold, siege cities, upgrade your armies, get dragons, tame/kill ogres, kill demn unicorns, burn orc villages, burn trents and their sacred elf woods, burn human cities, actually burn and kill everything that moves or not, and loot their bodies, because why not?, you won't regret it

reviewText: This game is one of my favorite RTS games of all time, but it is also still in progress, which means it can only improve from its current state (Still great in its current state). I have about 90 hours in the game at the moment, but with the new progress on the game right now, I can't wait to get back into the game. The developers are communicative and work with community to make the game better for everyone. The game reqiures strategic units and positioning to overcome defenses and overwhelming numbers. Kingdom Wars also allows you to make a town from scratch and build it into a fortress, along with controlling massive armies to conquer the many cities on the map. The progression of your city is slow but that make every little addition to your city feel huge. The campaign is mostly missions to keep you busy and have something interesting to do, but they give a good amount of gold. You are allowed to choose between three races: elves, humans, and orcs. Each have their own strengths and defenses, which means a variety of different play styles, thus giving the game replay value if you ever wish to restart. I definitely would recommend this game to any of my friends because it also allows you to team up with them to take down strongholds and do missions. If I was to rate this game on a scale of 1 to 10, I would say it was a 12. Kingdom Wars is phenomenal and I can't wait to see what they have in store for it in the future.

reviewText:
So Dawn of Fantasy: Kingdom Wars now just known as Kingdom Wars is a rather unique MMORTS with a persistent world and economy.

So let's go over this with the good the bad and the improving.

The Good:
This game has one of the most ACTIVE dev/moderator communities I've ever seen. There are almost always devs or moderators with community supporting abilities online and they respond very quickly to player queries/problems/bug reports.

City Management: It's really fun getting your city up and running, your economy working and it really helps build up a feeling of This is mine!" when you log in to your city.

Army building: The roster of units per race is not overly large or cumbersome but there is room for a lot of diversity and tactics. The way they go about this is fairly fun and unique.

Each and every battalion levels up  not just the heroes. And as each battalion levels you can allocate points to that battalion so that it better supports your tactics which means you can have two players with say a swordsman battalion and each sword battalion can be the exact same level but be specced out in two totally different ways.

This leads to a lot of fun with building YOUR ideal army rather than some all encompassing army of win that so many RTS games have.

Battles: Battles in terms of PVP are done via matchmaking which means you won't generally have to worry about armies many times your strength coming down to slaughter you while the veteran player at their helm laughs at the newbie. DON'T be mistaken though because it is fully possible to have two armies of identical strength rating but with totally different power ratios.
This can lead to some unforgiving learning cures where you need to figure out ideal combinations to match your strategy. Do you want quantity or quality do you want an ideal mix of both? Are you a player that can micro manage good enough to have a small crack corps of heroes over an army of regular soldiers? ALL of these options and combinations thereof are waiting for you to figure out.

PVE: The PVE options to take and conquer AI cities is fun especially when you get co-op up and running and can work together with other players to take particularly difficult targets.

Quest system: The quest system while nothing special allows you to earn some extra money and resources while not having to do the more challenging PVE or potentially unforgiving PvP battles.

Opt Out: You can "pay off" a player that wants to attack one of your armies or your town so as not to potentially risk losing units you otherwise do not want to lose. This is a good thing as the above mentioned potentially unforgiving early PvP learning curve may cost you questing time/ability.


So let's move on to the Bad:
Right now you have a few severe bugs that while not game breaking for MOST can become so for the less patient or mature players amongst us. If you get easily frustrated with bugs and don't like having to report them or talk to moderators to get your lost resources/gold/whatever back then at the moment I'd recommend holding off on this game.

Can be unforgiving: As stated with the battles section of "the good" this game can be VERY unforgiving when you lose a battle since this is a persistent world those losses are for good and some players might take days to rebuild from the loss of their core army.
While most of the community is currently rather friendly and often willing to help new players with tips and tricks on how to get your economy up and running the early losses that players WILL suffer can sometimes be a little spirit breaking until you figure out how to create newer better armies and get a solid economy running.


So lets move on to the "Needs improvement":

So far the idea that the game is "pay to win" can kind of seem like a thing for new players because of the way crowns work and how slowly they come in for a new player.

In truth I think the crown price of some units could afford to be lowered but this is personal preference.

There are bugs that definitely need to be sorted out before this game can be a 10/10 and some of the promised features need to be implemented such as the naval options and the like before I can say this game is truly what the developers advertise.


So for now at it's current stage I have to give this a 8/10 because it is not really "feature complete". There are bugs some of which can ruin an impatient/less mature player's experience. On the flip side the devs/moderators are extremely active and very willing to help people with any losses they've suffered and for such a small team (6 developers) they are fairly active in attempting to patch and bring this game up to a full 10/10."

reviewText:
I love this game cant stop playing it,I havent got to do any pvp yet as my army aint strong enought but looking foward to it also you dont have to spend a penny of your money to win its all completely free.
I would recommend doing the tutorial first it dose'nt take long and shows you enough to get started.

Pros..
as always everything uses resources but they are easy to come by you either farm for them using your peasants, trade goods and livestock for gold to buy them or just buy them with what gold you have instock by going to other towns you can also gather resources by taking peasants out with you to combat to loot the bodys.
The building side of the game is easy just click on the building you want to construck and it starts building, it takes time and patients but feels great when you finish, I cant wait till i have a full sized kingdom.
When it come to the army its so much fun watching the battles im impressed with the way you can control your individual units unlike some mmo's where its hard to control and keep track of your men this game tops it, the controls are easy just assinge a group to a hotkey and access them at a touch of a button, also the different formations prove very useful when in combat.
If your not ready to go out and attack a fort then just go out and you can fight againt pvp who have the same sized army as you,combat is great fun i love watching a hundred men battle it out but its not just a case of run in and chop away you have to be very strategic plan your moves and organise you army accordingly.

Cons..
I have only one problem.
It can get rather expensive on resouces as you kingdom grows so it take a long time to progress.

Overall this game is great so get it a.s.a.p

reviewText:
The best way to describe this game is by this short sentence: Real time strategy meets MMO".
We all know that will be your response.
Well yeah .... the question is ... is it good?
Short answer: Yes.
Long answer: It's complicated.
The good:
- it's free
- the tech tree is quite well defined and the progession is not to difficult
- the units have nice upgrades at level up (and yes the units level up)
date:
and it makes sense to have a main army that you carefully level up to a good level and have that as the main force in PVP later on
- the map is quite large and you have the possbility to set small strongholds around the home city to further protect yourself
- the game continues when you are not online (this feature is exaclty what I was searching for)
- large armyes
- ok graphics

The bad:
- it has quite a few bugs(units sometimes walk thru walls

The bonus ( :D ):

reviewText: In my opinion any game that gives you 1 hour of fun per dollar spent on it is worth. That said, I spent 20$ on this game a year ago and I have never regretted it. Now that it's free, there is zero reason why you shouldn't at least try this game :D It took me 75 hours and about 4 months of playing to get one built up city and I haven't even touched the other two races yet, so needless to say this game will occupy you for a while. Also zero pay to win advantages, everything is aesthetic. You can buy in-game currency with gold you acquire in the game, and now that's the only way you can get it so everyone's on the same level.

reviewText:
Kingdom Wars is a very interesting game. At first I had a very low opinion of it, but if you can overcome the first hour of the game and look past its shortcomings you'll find a very addictive experience with so much potential.


Negative impressions: Visually it looks as if it made in the early 2000s, and the combat leaves a lot to be desired. Once battle is joined unit formations devolve into disorganized mosh-pit like globs with very poor unit collision detection (if any at all.) The animations are primitive and very basic, not just in combat but for walking, idle, and cutscenes dialog. There are also a host of bugs, many of which are highly destructive and infuriating. The worst I encountered was when I lost an entire army, 28 units, because a quest sent them into a void and left me with an empty army on the map- without even starting the quest. I was left without my hero unit, and an entire day worth of invested resources that I used to build said army.

Positive Impressions: The economic system and a load of fun, and by far the best part of the game aside from the general idea. You can make profits by trading, harvesting resources, looting battlefields, and questing. Each option presents its own benefits and challenges. If you decide to harvest resources at home then you will looking at the safest and most reliable way, but it also means you need peasants working the land which drags on your unit cap. Trade is the quickest way, but it also means you’re at risk of losing caravans and thus your cargo. It also requires more management and the natural risk of losing money on a trade if you’re too hasty.

The game has a pretty mild pace, which is certainly a positive in my opinion. You won’t become powerful overnight, and all buildings and soldiers take quite a bit of resources and time to make. There is also a healthy variety of units and plenty of defining traits to pick from. Units gain experience from battles which lets you upgrade them, in addition to researching new technologies and equipment. From what I can tell there is no pay-to-win advantage either. The cashhop is purely aesthetics and speeding up the process of questing rewards.

If the combat would be overhauled then I think this would be an easy game to recommend, and if animations and visuals where modernized then it would be a jewel. However as it stands it’s a give and take. If you can overlook its issues there is a lot of fun to be had, but not everyone can do that.

reviewText:
An excellent game overall, that will immerse most RTS players for at least a good few hours.
Its fairly simple, with a very traditional setup of the three factions with strenghts and weaknesses. such as the Humans being the most durable overall, the Elves essentially having the strongest units but with greater weaknesses, and the Orcs being oddly enough the most frail but boasting the ability to quickly amass an army of considerable size at reduced cost.

(Please note: This is more of a quick run-down of some of the features in the game, than an review. The idea is that you can more effectively decide if its features appeals to you, rather than read someone trash n praise it)

Leveling up your units!:
This game relies quite heavily on the concept of your troops not simply being something you purchase enough of, in the right combination but actually take into skirmishes to level up or train at friendly strongholds, to then tailor suit what stats you want to improve, such as more health, damage mitigation, health regeneration, stamina, and so on.
Eventually you will pretty much max out all the stats but at that point you have spend quite a lot of gold on that unit, and considering its still very likely to get inconveniently killed while you look the other way you learn to pay special heed to keeping your investments alive and well protected.

Special Units:
Every faction has an array of faction specific units available to them, but theres also a common pool of special units available to all the factions. These units have roots in all three main factions, but theres also units from unplayable races, such as Dragons and Dwarves. These units almost always costs you Crowns, which is a measure of wealth and influence that you can spend on recruiting considerably attractive units to attack your enemies or defend your homeland.

Quest line:
Theres an rather involved lore in the game, and its often very nicely attached to the characters you interact with while playing the main quest line. As you go through the main quest of your faction your tasked with defending your homeland, your kingdom, and waging war against the two other factions in the game, and often also your own.
Due to the somewhat sandbox-like nature of the game, the senarios you find yourself in is often rather interesting and gradually gives you useful rewards that greatly benefit the construction of your homeland, giving a smooth progression of your homeland, the story of the game, and your involvement in the game overall.

Traits and Regions
In the MMO portion of the game, after choosing a faction you will be asked to choose a region and two traits.
These are important and should be chosen to match how you prefer to play the game. If your a turtle" and enjoys defensive gameplay then naturally you may want to choose the most defensive region and traits
date: but if your more into siege and conquest than naturally you would do well to take a region that reflects that better.\nEither way
recommended:
your choice of region and traits will play an immense factor in the performance of your strategies.
Choose wisely. :)

Non-Mandatory PvP
In the online MMO portion of the game you may be attacked by enemies at any time
hoursPlayed: but you need to actually accept the battle. Should you choose not to
voteText: or let the timer run out you will forfeit a small portion of your resources as a tribute to be left alone. Even if no resources are available fighting PvP is never mandatory. As you start out with a new homeland you will have 24 hours of real time protection against PvP attacks to get you started. Notice that this time is only ticking while your in-game. Additionally
helpfulPercent:
every time you pay a tribute or conclude a PvP match you will be given a small PvP Protection time.
It is also possible to purchase PvP protection for Crowns.

The graphics
votesHelpful: performance
votesTotal: and the gameplay itself have gradually improved over time
votesFunny: with updates coming out frequently enough for a game you only pay for once. (Not including the micro transaction-like boosts available in the market
commentsCount: and additional features)\nThe gameplay in singleplayer

reviewText: This game is really fun.  They say it is not pay to win, but seriously you really need a sub to get the double rewards.  The combat is awkward with too many units and they tend to cluster a lot.  That being said I really like the idea of owning my own little town and watching it go from nothing to a fortress.  The pvp is a little unfair and not enough people at the moment for it to be fair.  Each race has a differing economy, so far I would say that the elves have the best.  The do not need to drop off minerals at a spot they just keep working and it magically goes into your inventory.  I have not played the orcs yet, but the humans are pretty good too.  It can be a real bummer to get wiped out in pvp or a siege, so don't do these things until you are maxxed out.  What makes it so fun for me is the city building.  That's why I give it a thumbs up.

reviewText: I really liked this game (I really hated it in the  beginning) after the first day or two. Before, I didn't go through the tutorials (which I recommend you do) so I just asked around in the global chat. Luckily, there are about one million people that can help. reviewText:
Genius game!

Pros: Slowpased fighting and building which gives you a lot of time to figure out strategies.
Fighting mechanics are very easy to understand when you've played a few games.
Should be lag free on most computers



Cons: Tutorial needs a lot of improvement. It only teaches you how a small part of the humans works. If you want to play any other race as first race, you'll barely understand anything of the game. I began as elves, played for a short while and was then going to uninstall the game, because it was confusing. Luckily I decided to try humans, and that's how I learned the game. So basically you can skip tutorial, it doesn't teach you anything, other than the things you learn from every other game you play. It totally forgets the things it's supposed to teach, like what's unique about this game.

reviewText:
I find the game quite enjoyable. You manage a small village which, slowly, grows to metropolis. You have to decide on whats best for your village, paying off bandits, or deciding where to build the new blacksmith. The town is tailored to your design, be ye human, filthy orc, or hippy elf. The games graphics are pretty good considering the amount of individual units  each moving. You can see it at its best in the environmental changes, the winter was nice thing to in the game, although not for my peasants who were unable to plow the fields.

Although the game does have its fair share of bugs mostly in the ai. The most notable were my peasants choosing to drop resources at my keep instead of a cart which was right next to them, and a dragon swarmed by footmen trying to attack my dragon slayer in the back stuck and not attempting to attack anything else. My least favorite thing about the game is the fact that you have pay money in order to have additional towns with a different race. It saddens me that i can't even try out another race without paying 5 $ or deleting my first town, im fine that you can buy boosters (Its not pay to win, you are matched against players with equal army strength) but atleast let me try the other races.

Overall a fun free game 8.5/10

reviewText:
Kingdom Wars is an RPG Indie-Strategy game. It takes place long ago. You can choose from being Elves, Men, or Orcs. You are also able to choose from three different starting locations. As you progress through the game, you learn more and more about the lore. I, truly, very much like this game. It has all the things I like. If you have ever played Sid Meier's Civilization IV, Beyond the Sword/Warlords, or Civilization V, you will notice a lot of similarities. This game will keep you occupied for hours, and I, personally, reccomend this game to people like me who LOVE old fighting styles, and LOVE a good RPG/Strategy game.

9.5/10

I'm sure there are many great things to come with this game.

reviewText:
Extremely horrible game. I thought it would be like Age of Empires II but it's even worse than Age of Empires I. The movement is clunky, the interface doesn't work well and you have to level up/upgrade almost everything. It is way more similar to a click-farm like maybe Clash of Clans / Utopia. This is a city-builder, not an MMORTS.

PROS
1. Unsure

CONS
1. PvP Protection?
You can build it later in the game to buy PvP Protection. You can build a building to buy PvP Protection.

2. Crowns
Almost every good building is limited by Crowns, which you get on quests.

3. Movement
Extremely slow.

4. AI
Your hero just runs off and attacks the nearest creature within visible range. You can't move the hero away with a right-click because there is some attack-move encoded.

5. Graphics
Horrible. How could a game have worst graphics than an older game? e.g. Age of Empires II

reviewText:
To be clear, the game is free; payment only gives you access to two one-use-only-ever chests of resources which you don't need one bit. There are also a couple DLCs, but if you look at development/patch notes you realise the vanilla game is rich and you won't want to pay for the stupid DLCs even into late game (e.g. there's a SP-only dlc - for the incompetent only). Please read on.

3 races to choose from. Build your city, your army, your garrison, whatever labour forces you may want. Two very important factors that I find separate this game from those you may think this is similar to (involving MMO strategy games with building a settlement):
1) You can't be attacked when offline. If you're not logged in and playing, you can't be attacked - meaning you don't need to worry or dedicate ANY time to this game. (You also have a cancellable 24hr-game-time-only battle protection for noobs, after which you'll have a great base. Additionally, battles are always between similar-strength forces).
2) Your buildings can't be destroyed beyond 1% health. No conflict you will ever have will reset your city. Your buildings will be repaired over time and you'll just lose a token amount of resources, from what I understand you'll even get a few crowns (useful for upgrades or renaming units etc).

I recommend, if you have any interest in a forgiving MMO RTS game with visual battles and really quite rich content, you should download and try a couple of the races. Read the descriptions to see what you'd be interested in and have a go. Just be wise on how you spend your crowns in the beginning as they're earned through quests (story line), battles, daily-gift of 1 crown if you login and trading in gold. P.S. you will want to make gold one of your primary mining operations, because if you shop around at some NPC towns/cities, you can usually buy more than 100 of any resource with 100 gold.

I first tried the orcs (about 8 hrs), which I liked but I didn't do very well with.. Then I went to try the elves (now 14 hrs) and I love them. I don't get to design my city layout because we build in trees... but it's fun enough. Check out some of my woodelf screenshots.

reviewText:
Well i may not have played for a long period of time in this game and it seems like i cannot login into the game now due to some bugs. I still think this is a good game overall, which is why even after i encounter a rare bug which still have had yet to be solved and the developers are working on it.

The pros and cons are much like what other players have posted out in the reviews. I personally think the most attractive thing about kingdom wars are the pvp system and city protection shield. Unlike other games, this city protection shield only tickles when you are online on your kingdom and playing. When you go offline, your shield will be the same as when you login again. That is extremely attractive for players like me who are busy at work with little time to play games everyday. In other games, you will normally get sieged and lose resources or even the whole kingdom and you have to restart again which is very frustrating. Here, you can take things slowly as you want, explore the maps, conquer some npc cities or co-op siege with the community. If you have the time and army, you can just remove your shield and get onto some pvp for more fun.

There are no worries on how you play and whether if there are overpowered players that pays to win as everyone is more or less the same depending on what strategy you use and time spent to experience the game. I hope everyone finds it fun to play too.
